title: What do Vision Transformers Learn? A Visual Exploration

last_post.content:
"What do vision transformers learn? A visual exploration."

Vision transformers (ViTs) have fewer inductive biases the convolutional networks, so, what do ViTs actually learn? It turns out that they learn inductive biases (or features) similar to convolutional networks!

Early layers capture edges and textures, and later layers learn more complex representations to capture broader concepts.

Paper: "What do vision transformers learn? A visual exploration." (https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06727)

Today on @Wired I argue that we, by which I mean narrowly the media, but more broadly everybody, have fallen into the same trap with Elon Musk as we did with Donald Trump. They largely lived & worked in neutral countries in Latin America, Europe & Africa, where Nazis sought to cultivate allies or gain an advantage.

title: Ele-Math – Mathematical Inequalities & Applications: Why Hölder's inequality should be called Rogers' inequality

last_post.content:
Interesting for me to learn (via http://mia.ele-math.com/01-05/Why-Holder-s-inequality-should-be-called-Rogers-inequality):

"Hölder's inequality" was first proven in 1888 by L.J. Rogers.

In Hölder's paper of 1889, he includes this result, accurately attributing it to Rogers.

By luck of early citations (including from some big names of the time), the result is now known near-universally as "Hölder's inequality".

The author of this article subsequently advocates for using "Rogers-Hölder Inequality" going forward.

#maths #mathshistory
